answers.answer: I went through surgical menopause at the age of 37 due to early staged ovarian cancer.  I am not able to take hormones, so my experience was sudden and dramatic.  If you can take hormones after the surgery, you probably won't experience the changes that I did.  But, without hormones it has been very hard for me.  In the three years since my surgery, I have developed osteoporosis, lack of libido, vaginal dryness and noticed an overall aging of my body greater than would be expected for my age.  In the beginning, my hot flashes were very intense and frequent!!!   But, I do not have them anymore.  It was really hard to deal with the changes.  Since you are only 39, I would absolutely recommend that you take the hormones if you have the surgery.  Studies have shown that women are at greater risk for long term health problems like heart disease and diabetes due to the loss of estrogen.  It is protective for our blood vessels, skin and brain.  Sometimes, though, having your ovaries removed can't be avoided.  Your cyst that is 6.8cm should definitely be removed surgically and I doubt that ovary can be spared.  Good luck to you!Shelly

question: So I have been having problems with ovarian cysts, it is 6.8 right now having alot of pain. Suffered with endo for years now, had a hysterectomy 3 years ago and now my endo is back with all the pain especially in my back.  Still have my ovaries but my gyno feels I need to have my ovaries out now.  I am afraid of what it is going to be like once I go into surgical menopause.  I am sure there is someone out there who has gone thru this and I was wondering how their experience was, and if they had to go onto hormones or not?
title: ovarian cysts having ovaries removed
